access.description: The registered URL is a direct link to a PDF file hosted on the vendor's WordPress site. No redirects, no anti-bot protection, no JavaScript required. A simple HTTP GET returns the PDF with a 200 status. The file is publicly accessible without authentication, though it is marked 'AZZLY CONFIDENTIAL' in the footer.

products.name: AZZLY Rize

product_context.description: AZZLY Rize is a cloud-based, all-in-one EHR, practice management, and revenue cycle management (RCM) platform built exclusively for behavioral health and addiction treatment organizations. It is hosted on Microsoft Azure and targets outpatient mental health, intensive outpatient programs, residential treatment centers, MAT/OTP programs, and telehealth-based behavioral health providers. The product includes clinical documentation (assessments, treatment plans, progress notes, outcome measurements like PHQ-9/GAD-7), e-prescribing with EPCS, PDMP integration, integrated billing/RCM with claims submission and clearinghouse integration, appointment scheduling with electronic check-in, a Patient Engagement Portal (PEP) with secure messaging, integrated Zoom telehealth, document management, a bed board for residential facilities, and withdrawal management modules. The certified module IS the product — AZZLY Rize is the only product from this vendor. However, the certification profile is remarkably limited: only (a)(12) Family Health History, (a)(15) Social/Behavioral Data, (b)(10) EHI Export, (e)(3) Patient Health Info Capture, plus security and general criteria. No core clinical criteria (a)(1)-(a)(9), no patient portal certification (e)(1), no FHIR API (g)(7)-(g)(10). This suggests minimum certification for CHPL listing.

export_approach.description: The export is a vendor-mediated file delivery via Microsoft Azure Blob Storage. Users submit an 'Authorized User's Written Request' to AZZLY, who then uploads data files to an Azure Storage Container and provides a SAS (Shared Access Signature) URL. Users download Azure Storage Explorer to access the files. The data is organized into four folders: Clinical Data Forms (individual patient forms from eChart), Clinical Data Form Details (CSV listing every form with metadata), Data (structured CSV/Excel files with chart fields like allergies, diagnoses, medications, etc.), and Patients (photos and uploaded documents). This is a proprietary flat-file export — not database-native tables, not FHIR, not C-CDA. The documentation contradicts itself by stating users can export 'without developer assistance' while simultaneously requiring a written request and vendor-provided SAS URL.

documentation_quality.description: The entire EHI export documentation is a 3-page PDF. Page 1 contains regulatory compliance language and the summary of the export process. Pages 2-3 contain step-by-step instructions for downloading Azure Storage Explorer and connecting to the blob container, with screenshots. The description of actual export contents is limited to a single paragraph listing data category names (Allergies, Contact details, Diagnosis, Level of Care, Medications, Patient Communications, Patient Info, Insurance, Vitals 'etc.') with no field-level detail whatsoever. There is no data dictionary, no schema documentation, no field definitions, no data types, no value sets, no relationship documentation, and no examples. The 'etc.' at the end of the data categories list is particularly unhelpful — it implies additional data exists but is not documented. This is among the least detailed EHI export documentation possible while still technically existing.

ehi_coverage.overall_assessment: The export documentation describes a modest set of clinical and administrative data categories but conspicuously omits billing/financial data despite AZZLY Rize being a full RCM platform. The documentation is so sparse (listing only category names with no field detail) that it is impossible to assess true completeness. The Data folder covers 9 named categories: Allergies, Contact details, Diagnosis, Level of Care, Medications, Patient Communications, Patient Info, Insurance, and Vitals. Clinical forms from the eChart are exported as individual documents. Photos and uploaded documents are included. However, the product's core billing/RCM capabilities, scheduling system, e-prescribing records, PDMP queries, telehealth sessions, outcome measurements, withdrawal management data, and bed board information are all absent from the documentation. For a product that markets itself as 'all-in-one' EHR + practice management + RCM, exporting only clinical chart data represents a significant gap in EHI coverage.

clinical.evidence: The Data folder includes Allergies, Diagnosis, Medications, Vitals, and Level of Care. Clinical Data Forms folder contains assessments, treatment plans, progress notes, and other forms from the eChart. Clinical Data Form Details CSV provides form metadata including dates, times, signatures, and finalizing user. However, there is no explicit mention of problem lists, immunizations, procedures, lab results, family health history (despite (a)(12) certification), social/behavioral data (despite (a)(15) certification), or outcome measurement scores (PHQ-9, GAD-7). The trailing 'etc.' may cover some of these gaps.

secure_messages.evidence: 'Patient Communications' is listed as one of the data categories in the Data folder. This likely represents secure messages or patient-provider communications from the Patient Engagement Portal. However, there is no detail on what this includes — it could be comprehensive messaging history or merely communication preferences/contact records. The product has a Patient Engagement Portal (PEP) with secure messaging, so substantial communication data should exist.

billing_financial.evidence: No billing, financial, charge, claim, payment, or transaction data is mentioned anywhere in the 3-page documentation. This is a significant omission: AZZLY Rize is marketed as an all-in-one EHR and RCM platform with integrated billing, claims submission, claims scrubbing, clearinghouse integration, and a claimed 98% first-time claims pass rate. The product clearly stores substantial billing and financial data, but the export documentation makes no mention of it. This is the most notable gap.

insurance_coverage.evidence: 'Insurance' is listed as one of the data categories in the Data folder. No detail on what fields are included — could range from basic payer name to comprehensive eligibility, authorization, and benefits data.

appointments_scheduling.evidence: No appointment, scheduling, calendar, check-in, or visit data is mentioned in the export documentation. The product has a full scheduling system with individual and group appointments, electronic check-in, automated reminders, and attendance tracking. This data is absent from the documented export.

documents_images.evidence: The Patients folder contains 'photos and any uploaded documents.' Clinical Data Forms folder contains individual patient forms from the eChart. This covers patient photos and clinical documents but there is no mention of scanned external documents, faxes, or other attachments beyond these two categories.

issues: Billing/RCM data entirely absent from export despite being a core product capability — AZZLY Rize markets itself as an all-in-one EHR + RCM platform but the EHI export excludes all financial data.
Scheduling/appointment data absent from export despite the product having a full scheduling system.
Vendor-mediated export process contradicts 'without developer assistance' claim — requires written request and vendor-provided SAS URL.
Documentation is only 3 pages with zero field-level detail — data categories are listed by name only with no schema, no field definitions, no data types.
Trailing 'etc.' in data category list is vague and makes completeness assessment impossible.
E-prescribing and PDMP data not explicitly mentioned despite being key product features for addiction treatment.
Behavioral health-specific data (withdrawal management, outcome measurements, bed board) not mentioned in export.
Documentation dated September 2023 — nearly 2.5 years old with no apparent updates.
PDF marked 'AZZLY CONFIDENTIAL' despite being publicly accessible per ONC requirement.
products.summary: AZZLY Rize's EHI export documentation is a minimal 3-page PDF describing a vendor-mediated Azure Blob Storage delivery of CSV/Excel files. While it covers basic clinical data categories (allergies, diagnoses, medications, vitals, insurance, patient communications, and clinical forms), it conspicuously omits billing/financial data despite the product being a full RCM platform, and excludes scheduling data despite having a complete scheduling system. The documentation provides no field-level detail whatsoever, making it impossible to assess true completeness beyond category names.

downloaded_files.description: Complete EHI export documentation — 3-page PDF with process instructions for accessing Azure Blob Storage container and brief description of export folder structure and data categories. No data dictionary or field-level documentation.

summary: AZZLY Rize is a behavioral health and addiction treatment EHR/RCM platform with a minimal 3-page EHI export documentation PDF. The export delivers CSV/Excel files via vendor-mediated Azure Blob Storage, covering basic clinical categories (allergies, diagnoses, medications, vitals, insurance, patient communications, clinical forms, photos/documents) but entirely omitting billing/financial data and scheduling — despite these being core product capabilities. The documentation provides zero field-level detail, listing only category names. The most significant gap is the complete absence of billing/RCM data from a product that markets integrated revenue cycle management as a primary feature.
notes: AZZLY Rize has an unusually limited ONC certification profile — only (a)(12), (a)(15), (b)(10), (e)(3) plus security/general criteria. No core clinical (a)(1)-(a)(9), no patient portal (e)(1), no FHIR API (g)(7)-(g)(10). This suggests the vendor pursued minimum certification to maintain CHPL listing rather than comprehensive certification of product capabilities. The product has significantly more functionality than what is certified, which makes the EHI export gap even more notable — the export should cover 'all EHI that can be stored by the product, of which the Health IT Module is a part,' meaning all of AZZLY Rize's data, not just the certified features.
